conversation.content: The Hartmans' embryos have been in our care for seven years now, and every morning when I check the cryogenic storage, I think about what they would have wanted.
[gently] That's why we're here, to document this process with the sensitivity it deserves, though I have to admit I've never recorded something quite this intimate before.
They're viable still.
How many couples go through this, leaving embryos behind without clear instructions about what should happen if they both... [trails off]

[soft exhale] More than you'd think, and each situation tears at me differently because these aren't just biological material, they're potential lives that someone desperately wanted to bring into the world.
[adjusting equipment quietly] The way you speak about them, it's clear this isn't just clinical work for you—there's something deeply personal happening here.
Sarah Hartman used to bring me homemade cookies every appointment, and she'd ask me to play classical music near the storage units because she believed it would help somehow.
Did you? [pause]
[barely audible] Every single day since the accident, I've played Chopin's Nocturnes on my phone next to their storage unit, just five minutes each morning before anyone else arrives.
[moved] That's something I want to capture in the audio, not just the facts of the case but these quiet acts of care that happen when no one's watching.
[lingering on the thought] The court wants a recommendation by Friday about whether to donate them to research, offer them for adoption, or... the other option that nobody wants to say out loud.
[carefully] What do you think they would have chosen, based on everything you knew about them during those years of treatments and conversations?
[voice catching] They had names picked out already—Emma, James, and Lily—written on a little card Sarah kept in her wallet that the police returned to us with her effects.
[softly] Names make everything more real, don't they? Suddenly it's not about embryos but about Emma, James, and Lily who never got their chance.
[steadying] Which is why I'm recommending embryo adoption, even though the Hartmans' parents are fighting it, saying it would be too painful to know their grandchildren are out there somewhere.
[thoughtful pause] The grandparents' pain is real too, but those names suggest the Hartmans saw these embryos as their future children, not just potential ones.
[resolved] Tomorrow I'll submit my report, and then Emma, James, and Lily will have a chance at the life their parents dreamed of, just with different people to love them.
Would you mind if I recorded you playing the Chopin tomorrow morning, one last time? [gentle pause]
[whispered] I think Sarah would have liked that, knowing someone else understood why the music mattered, why all these small rituals we create around loss actually mean something.
[accepting] Then I'll be here at 6 AM with my equipment, and we'll give them a proper goodbye with the music their mother believed would keep them company all these years.

scenario: A production sound mixer documents an embryologist who must make a recommendation about the fate of embryos left behind by a couple who died in an accident seven years ago.
